facts.text: The appellant was the proprietor of the Narmada Printing Works, Jabalpur.

facts.text: Island territories of Laccadive, Minicoy and Amindivi Islands omitted from every map of India.

anchor.surface_text: Besides this, the island territories of Laccadive, Minicoy and Amindivi Islands which form an integral part of India are omitted together from every map of India.

facts.text: High Court of Madhya Pradesh dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh took the view that the impugned order companyld number be said to have omitted to state the grounds for the opinion of the State Government.

facts.text: High Court held that the order stated the grounds as books contained matter questioning territorial integrity prejudicial to safety and security of India.

anchor.surface_text: According to the High Court the grounds on which the said opinion was based were that the books companytained matter which questions the territorial integrity and frontiers of India in a manner which is likely to be prejudicial to the interest of the safety and security of India.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the High Court was wrong and the order did not disclose the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court had clearly gone wrong in this view of the law on the subject. According to the Oxford Dictionary the meaning of the word ground, in this companynection must be base, foundation, motive, valid reason.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated March 13, 1969 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Miscella-

S. 2. Whoever by words either spoken or written, or by signs, or by visible representation or otherwise, questions the territorial integrity or frontiers of India in a manner which is, or is likely to be prejudicial to the interests of the safety or security of India, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

concepts.interpretation: Matter in publication punishable if it questions territorial integrity or frontiers prejudicial to safety or security of India.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: which was or was likely to be prejudicial to the interests of the safety or security of India. The relevant provisions of the Act are as follows - S.

concepts.unlisted_description: Defines offence of questioning territorial integrity of India prejudicially

anchor.surface_text: 4.  1  Where any newspaper or book as defined in the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867, or an other document, wherever printed, appears to the State Government to contain an matter the publication of which Is punishable under section 2 or sub-section  2  of section 3, the State Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, stating the grounds of its opinion, declare every copy of the issue of the newspaper containing such matter and every copy of such book or other document to be forfeited to the Government, and thereupon any police officer may seize the same wherever found and any Magistrate may, by warrant authorise any police officer not below the rank of Sub-Inspector to enter upon and search for the same in any premises where any copy of such issue or any copy of such book or other document may be or may be reasonably suspected to be.

concepts.interpretation: Requires notification stating the grounds of opinion that publication contains matter punishable under s.2; grounds must be conclusions of facts, not mere recitation of statutory language.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to forfeit publications containing matter punishable under s.2, requiring statement of grounds of opinion

anchor.surface_text: 5.  1  Any person having any interest in any news book or other document in respect of which an forfeiture has been made under section 4 may, within two months from the date of such order, apply to the High Court to set aside such order on the ground that the issue of the newspaper, or the book or other document in respect of which the order was made did not contain any matter of such a nature  as is referred to in sub- section  1  of section 4. The provisions of sections 99-C to 99-F of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, shall apply in relation to an application under sub- section  1  as they apply in relation to an application under section 99-B of that Code and the reference in section 99-D to seditious or other matter of such a nature as is referred to in subsection  1  of section 99-A of that Code shall be construed as reference to any matter of such a nature as is referred to in sub-section  1  of section 4 of this Act. No order passed or action taken under section 4 shall be called in question in any Court otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of this section.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for application to High Court within 2 months to set aside forfeiture order; incorporates CrPC ss.99B-99F procedures.

issues.text: Whether the order of the State Government forfeiting the book under Section 4(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1961 disclosed the grounds of its opinion

anchor.surface_text: can be disposed of on the short ground that the order did number disclose the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government. The Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1961  hereinafter referred to as the Act  empowered the State Governments by s. 4 to make order declaring any newspaper or book as defined in the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867 or any other document wherever printed, to be forfeited to the Government if it appeared to the Government that the said book etc. questioned the territorial integrity or frontiers of India in a manner which was or was likely to be prejudicial to the interests of the safety or security of India.

issues.text: Whether the grounds for the opinion of the State Government were non-existent in the forfeiture order as required by Section 4 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: challenging the order of the 1st July 1967 inter alia on the ground That the grounds for the opinion of the State Government which had to be given in terms of s. 4 of the Act were number-existent in the order. He therefore filed the petition, within two months of the date of the order forfeiting the book in terms of s. 5 of the Act. In the companynter affidavit of the State the stand taken was that the State Government was number bound to place details of information on the basis of which its satisfaction was arrived at.

issues.text: Whether merely quoting the words of Section 2 in the forfeiture order constitutes stating the grounds of opinion

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court had clearly gone wrong in this view of the law on the subject. According to the Oxford Dictionary the meaning of the word ground, in this companynection must be base, foundation, motive, valid reason. what the State Government did in this case in the opening paragraph of the order was merely to quote a portion of the words of s. 2 namely, that the books questioned the territorial integrity and frontiers of India in a manner which is likely to be prejudicial to the interest of the safety or security of India.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of opinion under Section 4(1) must be conclusions of facts on which the opinion is based

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the grounds must be distinguished from the opinion. Grounds of the opinion must mean the companyclusion of facts on which the opinion is based. There can be numberconclusion of fact which has numberreference to or is number ex facie based on any fact. The provisions of the Act have a close parallel in s. 99-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 in which a large number of matters are mentioned which according to the Government may lead it to form the opinion that the publication offended the said section.

arguments.court_reasoning: Merely quoting words of s.2; not grounds which require factual basis

arguments.claim: The order did not disclose the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government as required by s.4(1)

anchor.surface_text: can be disposed of on the short ground that the order did not disclose the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government. The Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1961  hereinafter referred to as the Act  empowered the State Governments by s. 4 to make order declaring any newspaper or book as defined in the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867 or any other document wherever printed, to be forfeited to the Government if it appeared to the Government that the said book etc. questioned the territorial integrity or frontiers of India in a manner which was or was likely to be prejudicial to the interests of the safety or security of India.

arguments.claim: Meaning of 'ground' is base, foundation, motive, valid reason; order merely quotes s.2 without indicating facts or statements offending s.2

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court had clearly gone wrong in this view of the law on the subject. According to the Oxford Dictionary the meaning of the word ground, in this connection must be base, foundation, motive, valid reason. what the State Government did in this case in the opening paragraph of the order was merely to quote a portion of the words of s. 2 namely, that the books questioned the territorial integrity and frontiers of India in a manner which is likely to be prejudicial to the interest of the safety or security of India.

arguments.claim: The order gives no indication of facts, statements, or representations in the book offending s.2; no reference to any map or text

anchor.surface_text: what the State Government did in this case in the opening paragraph of the order was merely to quote a portion of the words of s. 2 namely, that the books questioned the territorial integrity and frontiers of India ... The order gives no indication of the facts or the statements or the representations contained in the book which according to the State Government offended s. 2. In the order itself there is no reference to any map or any text in the book

arguments.claim: Grounds of opinion must mean conclusions of facts on which opinion based; cannot be without reference to facts

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the grounds must be distinguished from the opinion. Grounds of the opinion must mean the conclusion of facts on which the opinion is based. There can be no conclusion of fact which has no reference to or is not ex facie based on any fact. The provisions of the Act have a close parallel in s. 99-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 in which a large number of matters are mentioned which according to the Government may lead it to form the opinion that the publication offended the said section.

arguments.claim: In Mahomed Ali case under Press Act 1910, forfeiture notification insufficient if merely repeats section words without facts

anchor.surface_text: There are also decisions under the Indian Press Act which illustrate what the grounds in a case like this must be. In re. Mahomed Ali 1 , a case of an order of forfeiture of a pamphlet under the Press Act of 1910, the order of Government went to show that the pamphlet Come over to Macedonia and help us contained words of the nature described in s. 4 sub-s.  1  of the  1  41 Calcutta 466. Indian Press Act, 19 1 0

arguments.claim: In Harnam Das v. State of UP under CrPC s.99A, order forfeiting under IPC ss.153A/295A invalid for not specifying affected communities or beliefs

anchor.surface_text: In Harnam Das v. State of Uttar Pradesh  2   the order under s. 99-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure which was made went to show that the State Government declared the books forfeited on the ground that the said books contained matter the publication of which was Punishable under s. 153--A and 295-A of the Penal Code. The two sections of the Indian Penal Code have little in common inasmuch as s. 153-A relates to an offence of  1  59 C. W.N. 495.  2  1962 2 S.C.R. 487. promotion or attempt to promote feelings of enmity or hatred between different classes of citizens of India and s. 295-A relates to an offence maliciously intended to outrage he religious feelings of any such class by insulting the religion or the religious belief of that class.

arguments.claim: Under Art.22(5), grounds of detention are conclusions of facts to be communicated, enabling representation; similar here

anchor.surface_text: We may also refer to Art. 22 5  of the Constitution which lays down that when any person is detained in pursuance of an order made under any law providing for preventive detention, the authority making the order shall, as soon as may be, communicate to such person the grounds on which the order has been made

arguments.claim: In preventive detention cases like Naresh Chandra Ganguli, grounds are conclusions of facts to be communicated

anchor.surface_text: In considering the question as to what the grounds of detention meant when an order under Preventive Detention Act was made this Court said in Naresh Chanra, Ganguli v. The State of West Bengal others 1  . . the grounds for making an order of detention, which have to be communicated to the detenu as soon as practicable, are conclusions of facts, and those conclusions of facts have to be communicated to the detenu as soon as may be.

precedents.cited_proposition: Grounds of opinion mean the import, effect or tendency of matters contained in the offending publication, not the opinion itself.

precedents.cited_proposition: An order forfeiting books merely by referring to Penal Code sections without specifying which communities or beliefs were affected does not state the grounds of opinion.

anchor.surface_text: can be disposed of on the short ground that the order did number disclose the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government. The Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1961  hereinafter referred to as the Act  empowered the State Governments by s. 4 to make order declaring any newspaper or book as defined in the Press and Registration of Books Act, 1867 or any other document wherever printed, to be forfeited to the Government if it appeared to the Government that the said book etc. questioned the territorial integrity or frontiers of India in a manner which was or was likely to be prejudicial to the interests of the safety or security of India.
